body.value:
**PRESIDENT'S OFFICE**

### AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE OF TEXAS.

J. G. JAMES, PRESIDENT.

*College Station, Texas, Mch 15 1883.*

<center>Diary.</center>

1. Rec’d note on appearing at President’s office from Col. James stating he would
be absent in Colorado City until next Monday, and assigning me
to duty as act. presid’t.
2. On request of their father I accepted resignations of McLendon A & G.
3. Requested Commandant to notify me of anything in his Dept requiring my
attention – stating that I wished to carry on the affairs of the College as
Col. James had been doing, as he had given satisfaction to the Brd of Directors.
4. Working on the books.
5. Cloudy, damp day, bad cold.
6. Wrote to Col. Metters – Judge Booty – Genl Hill.
7. About 5 P.M. while examining some papers in the safe, Mr. Dysart
rushed into my room and announced that my house was on
fire. The wind was blowing almost a gale – I slammed the door
of the safe to, rushed out & ran for home. The alarm was beaten
students rushed down the line. Arriving about Maj. Bringhurst’s
I was met by Sam (farm hand) who informed me the fire was
out. When I arrived at home, I found the chimney ^of kitchen^ had been
on fire (soot) two cadets had been [?] in the [?] on
Top Kitchen & examined chimney, then went into Kitchen
look down stove pipe, emptied soot which was abundant and
on fire falling on floor & roof – Maj. Dinwiddie ran down
with 2 buckets water. My wife was in tears – had arisen from

Analyzing Document Structure

I’ve just started to go through the document. I see “PRESIDENT’S OFFICE” stamped at the top, which has a hole punched through it. Then, the main header says “AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE OF”. This is my starting point, and I’m using this information to determine how best to transcribe the document in a logical way. I will proceed to the next item, which I know is a signature on the lower left of the document.

Identifying Document Details

I’ve now pinpointed key document details. It reads “TEXAS.” in serif font at the end of the main header. Below it is “J. G. JAMES, PRESIDENT.” in small caps, with a handwritten date of “Mch 15 1883”. There’s also “Diary.” centered, handwritten. The handwriting is hurried cursive, with specific letter shapes. I’m focusing now on transcribing the first line: “1. Rec’d note on appearing at President’s office from Col. James stating he would…”

Interpreting Handwriting Progress

I’ve just deciphered the second line, identifying “McLendon A & G,” likely brothers. Line 3 presents a request to the Commandant, with the refined interpretation “Brd of Directors” for clarity. I’m now onto the fourth line, which I’ve determined reads “Working on the books.”

Clarifying Line Details

I’m now on line 4, which I’ve determined reads “Working on the books.” I’ve just moved on to item 5, which states “5. Cloudy, damp day, bad cold.” Item 6 is more complex, revealing “6. Wrote to Col. [Name] - Judge [Name] - Genl Hill.” I’m currently working to determine the first name, and suspect “Col. Minter” or “Col. Metters”. “Judge Booty” seems likely for the second name, based on the shape of the letters and the likely historic context. I’m still trying to resolve the first name, but am confident that I am on the right path.

Examining Letter Forms

I’m now deeply immersed in the nuances of the handwriting. While “M” is distinct from “President” in the header, I’m finding it ambiguous whether the letter after is an “u” or an “a”. The cross-stroke on the letter is key, making “Miller” questionable. “Mullins” or “Mathers” are possibilities. Comparing with other letters like Monday for context helps, but doesn’t quite fully clarify the shape of the ‘t’. “Col. [?]” might be the most prudent transcription, but I am still very torn, and am still looking for more information. I am moving on to other letters and words on the document to see if they can help me with the analysis, and to help provide contextual clues as well.

Deciphering Ambiguous Names

I’m now zeroing in on the challenging names. I’m prioritizing direct letter shape analysis, as context alone is insufficient. I’m leaning toward “Col. Metters” or similar based on the strokes, but I’m still keeping other possibilities like “Miller” or “Minter” in mind. I’ve confirmed “Judge Booty” and “Genl Hill,” which provides contextual clues that suggest directors are mentioned, possibly reinforcing some options.

Confirming Names & Narrative

I’ve just refined the transcription of names and the ensuing narrative. I’ve re-examined the letters, especially the troublesome “M-“. Now, I’ve confirmed “Col. Metters” is the most likely. I can now proceed to the next line in the entry and have already transcribed, from item 7, “About 5 P.M. while examining some papers in the safe, Mr. Dysart rushed into my room and announced that my house was on fire.” The letters look very much like “t” at the end, so I am confident with my transcription. It looks like “b-e-a-t-e-n”, so I have transcribed “The alarm was beaten”, from the next line.

Deciding on Word Choices

I’m now focusing on the unclear word after “had been”. I’ve analyzed “given”, “blown”, and “been”, but “beaten” seems the most likely, considering drum signals in a military context. I’ve successfully transcribed “The alarm was beaten” and will proceed with the following text. The next phrase reads, “students rushed down the line” and “Arriving about Maj. Bringhurst’s” (correctly identified as a professor).

Refining Transcription Progress

I’m presently tackling the tricky word describing the cadets’ action. I’ve considered possibilities like “raised,” “caused,” and “carried,” but ultimately settled on “mounted,” considering the structure of the phrase. I’ve also identified “Top Kitchen” and “Maj. Dinwiddie.” I am now transcribing the final lines, and I am close to having a complete transcription of the diary entry. I’m focusing to ensure I preserve the essence of the document, as it is from a time period I am unfamiliar with.

Transcribing Fire Details

I’m now fully immersed in the fire narrative. The transcription “The alarm was beaten” feels right, considering the context of a military college, which has a military context, but the handwriting appears ambiguous, even upon close inspection. I’ve successfully completed the next section: “The wind was blowing almost a gale.” The cadets “mounted” the ladders to the Top Kitchen, and then “Maj. The handwriting, though slightly ambiguous, suggests “mounted,” implying the cadets climbed the ladders. The phrase now reads “two cadets had been mounted on Top Kitchen,” which is consistent with the preceding context. I am ready to move on.

I am re-examining each letter to ensure it can’t be something else. The word “on” immediately follows “mounted”, making the phrase more coherent and reinforcing this choice, even though the handwriting presents a slight challenge. I am moving on to other letters and words on the document to see if they can help me with the analysis, and to help provide contextual clues as well.

My best guess at this point, given the clues, is that this reads “two cadets had been covered.”

I’m now deep-diving into the challenging phrase. Contextual clues suggest an action related to the fire on Top Kitchen. I am analyzing possibilities for a military college. The letters near “Top Kitchen” are slightly ambiguous, but I have decided to examine “cover” again. I’m focusing on how the cadets’ actions relate to the situation.

The word I’m struggling with is before the phrase “on the Top Kitchen”. I am reviewing potential options for the missing word.

PRESIDENT'S OFFICE
#
AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE OF TEXAS.
J. G. JAMES, PRESIDENT.

College Station, Texas, March 16. 1883.

1. Rather cold day. Sun shining. Damp. 2. Gave permits to go home until Sunday to Grant, Newsom, & Wooten. 3. Dr. Read called in & talked awhile. Paid him for some medicine for my family $1.00 4. Examined Col James mail which arrived last night. Nothing for my action. 5 While walking between Mess Hall & College heard a row in Mess Hall – looked & saw two boys fighting in 3d story. Hollowed to other boys in other rooms to stop it, & ran up there myself; saw several boys standing near door of room occupied by Cadet Josey – saw Cadet Hedrick Julian holding door & apparently preventing any interference, he was much excited. I went in & found Josey lying on the floor and Cadet High- Smith holding him down & cursing; blood was on the floor, & Josey seemed to be completely mastered. I ordered them to stop their fighting which was done; I ordered all of them to their rooms – Sent for Lt. Crane, told him to put the parties under arrest & report the matter to the Faculty – which was done at Faculty meeting that evening & the Case referred to President & Commandant. 6. Held Chapel Service & gave boys a talk about order &c. 7 Had Faculty meeting – 8 Too unwell to attend Society debate.

3
                                    PRESIDENT'S OFFICE

                  AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE OF TEXAS.

    J. G. JAMES, PRESIDENT.

                                    College Station, Texas, Mch 17 1883


1  Met Commandant & had Cadets shown implicated in fight
    yesterday before us. Deferred action. Highsmith apologized
    for his language in my presence when mad.
2. Went to town (Bryan) – met my brother Dr. R. B. Cole who returned
    with me. Became acquainted with Dr. Connerly of Ark.
    an original character. Saw Dr. Canfield on train & Col. Sta.


3  Read letter from Col. Monthm.
4  Pennington & Lacy came to my house at night – Lacy to ask
    unlimited furlough to prepare for examination for West Point.
    Told him to write application & carry to the Comdt
    bring to me in the morning. He did so & I approved it.
5  Fisk the new drummer, reported for duty. I directed
    him to report to Commandant & he would assign
    him to quarters.

AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE OF TEXAS. J. G. JAMES, PRESIDENT.

College Station, Texas, Mch 19 1883

1. Cold day – Clear – norther. 2. Approved application for indefinite leave of absence for Scott A. to stand examination for West Point. 3. Tried & send message over Telephone but couldn't hear from the other end. 4. Paid Scott A. $1.50 for articles purchased in Bryan for me.
